results.title: Hailstones and halibut bones. Part 2
results.brief_description: A sequel to Part 1, produced to illustrate the verses which make up the balance of the poem by Mary O’Neill from her book “Hailstones and halibut bones”. Uses animated drawings to depict the colors blue, grey, orange, purple and brown. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Hailstones and halibut bones. Part 1
results.creator_credit: John Wilson, Fine Arts and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: Celeste Holm reads selections from the poem “Hailstones and Halibut Bones” by Mary O’Neill. Animated drawings illustrate the poem, and show how the writer uses colour to convey feeling. White, gold, red, green and black are each described in a series of couplets. Some of the animated visuals, like the couplets themselves, are literal identifications whilst others reflect emotions and attitudes about colour. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Haida carver
results.creator_credit: Richard Gilbert and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A young Haida Indian artist shapes miniature totems from argillite, a stone-like jet. Shows the island where he finds the stone, and how he carves it in the manner of his grandfather who taught him the craft. His grandmother shows delight as she polishes each new piece to a gbeautiful black gloss. Weathered monuments stand among the tall firs on Canada’s Pacific coast, where the whittlers used to carve the giant totems.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Gilbert and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Habitat UK 76
results.creator_credit: Anthony Wilkinson, Michael Birkett and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: Discusses the problems of redevelopment of cities. Emphasises that circumstances forever change and uses Birmingham as an example that single, large-scale comprehensive approaches to planning may not be the best approach.

results.title: Habitat
results.creator_credit: National Film Board of Canada and United Nations Films
results.brief_description: Human habitat is any place where humans live. In the past most habitats were rural and posed relatively simple problems. At the moment, the human race is posing entirely new, and often complex problems. This film describes some of these problems and suggests some solutions

results.title: Habit Patterns
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology for Living”.
It’s a little late for tears, isn’t it Barabara? Says the brutal narrator at the beginning of the film. This instructional piece, as the title suggests, is for developing good habits. At the start of the film, Barbara stands by the closed door of her bedroom, weeping pitifully. She has bad habits, and this film sends her to social hell as we flash-back to the beginning of her day. She is sloppy and unorganised, sleeps in, and is generally discourteous. All the examples of problems caused by her bad habits in this film are social blunders, which get worse as the film progresses. The narrator is unforgiving: “How easy it is not to be invited again.” and “how quickly you can be left out of the crowd”. This film is more about conformity than keeping good habits.

results.title: Gymnosperms
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Defines gymnosperms and traces the life cycle of the pine. Shows examples of lesser-known gymnosperms and illustrates the importance of conifers.

results.title: Gymnastics in the primary school (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Based on the film ‘Free to Move’ this film shows the development of gymnastics along movement themes. It clearly demonstrates children working at floor level and the adaptation of these experiences on small and large equipment. Extremely informative for teachers who plan and teach from the ‘Physical Education Curriculum Guide No. 2 Gymnastics’.

results.title: The Gunpowder Man
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Eastern Suburb's Children's Film Group
results.brief_description:
In this short film, made in 1966, two children build a Guy Fawkes statue, but are spotted by a third child who reveals their secret to their classmates. The children fight over the statue and eventually join forces to light the bonfire together.

The burning of a Guy Fawkes effigy is a tradition that emerged in the UK, initially to commemorate the failure of a plot, known as the Gunpowder Plot, to assassinate King James I in London on 5 November 1605. In its modern form, the tradition is celebrated as more of a social gathering, with a display of bonfires and fireworks. In Australia, it has become less common since the 1970s.

This short film was sponsored by the Eastern Suburbs Children’s Film Group, Melbourne, and produced and directed by John Richardson. Written by John Richardson and Val Fairweather. Featured cast include Christopher Wilson, Scott McClung, Christopher Ely, Robert Bartnik, Ian Mathieson, Daniel Meltzer, Stephen Palamountain and Jamie Steuart.
